title: Head rush: cutting-edge tips and treatments in our good hair guide
description: Hot stylists, smart gadgets and miraculous serums… Here’s everything you need to make every day a good hair dayThere is something about hair that sparks conversations (and questions! So many questions!) often riddled with frustration. It is a reminder that our hair isn’t simply this thing that sprouts from our scalps. It is much more complex than that. It’s about the right products, people and places that help you achieve something that makes you feel amazing. Which we all want. Post summer, when we see our hair in a different (autumnal) light, makes us consider what we can do to make it thicker, shiner, stronger, fuller, healthier… And sometimes we simply want hair that looks less basic. The industry understands this all too well, which is why so many brands launch a ton of product and treatments at this time.We have sifted through many of their offerings and pulled together a hair special to tackle not every single question, but some of the key ones around hair that I hear time and time again. Why is the Dyson so expensive? How do I combat hair loss? What shampoos will give me thicker hair? Do supplements actually work? Who on social media might just inspire me to have a new style or simply embrace the one I already have? I can’t promise you we have all the answers you want, but hopefully it’s an inspiring start. Continue reading...

text: There is something about hair that sparks conversations (and questions! So many questions!) often riddled with frustration. It is a reminder that our hair isn’t simply this thing that sprouts from our scalps. It is much more complex than that. It’s about the right products, people and places that help you achieve something that makes you feel amazing. Which we all want. Post summer, when we see our hair in a different (autumnal) light, makes us consider what we can do to make it thicker, shiner, stronger, fuller, healthier… And sometimes we simply want hair that looks less basic. The industry understands this all too well, which is why so many brands launch a ton of product and treatments at this time.We have sifted through many of their offerings and pulled together a hair special to tackle not every single question, but some of the key ones around hair that I hear time and time again. Why is the Dyson so expensive? How do I combat hair loss? What shampoos will give me thicker hair? Do supplements actually work? Who on social media might just inspire me to have a new style or simply embrace the one I already have? I can’t promise you we have all the answers you want, but hopefully it’s an inspiring start.Let it shine: frazzled, dull, lacklustre? These smart products will helpBriogeo Yuzu + Plum Oil Sleek Stick, £20, cultbeauty.co.uk Most styling products – particularly those that help achieve a super-shiny look – are not as focused on hair health as they should be. Briogeo’s Yuzu + Plum Oil Sleek Stick includes nourishing and protective antioxidants and vitamins, so you can achieve that slick ponytail without compromising the health of the hair.Grown Alchemist Hydra-Restore Shampoo and Conditioner, £24 each, grownalchemist.com If you find your hair is still frazzled from the heat of your summer holidays, look no further than Grown Alchemist. Its new Hydra-Restore will gently exfoliate your scalp and give your hair a powerful injection of moisture.Leonor Greyl Energisant range, from £34.50, feelunique.com If your hair looks limp and lacklustre, try the new Energisant range, which includes shampoo, conditioner and treatment serum, from this sustainable, luxe Parisian haircare brand. Combining ingredients such as moringa seed, Indian plum and almond protein, it strengthens hair at the follicle (thereby reducing hair thinning) and adds body to the hair without weighing it down.Josh Wood Colour Miracle hair Oil, £15, joshwoodcolour.com Great colour comes down to incredible expertise and good aftercare. Hairstylist Josh Wood – the globally renowned, expert colourist delivers both. His latest launch is a versatile oil that manages frizz and also works as a pre-shampoo or overnight treatment and detangler. However you use it, you can expect shinier and softer locks that look amazing long after you’ve had your colour done.Colour Wow Dream Filter, £26, uk.colourwowhair.com Dull, brittle and breakage-prone hair are just some of the disadvantages of living in a hard water area. Colour Wow’s Dream Filter removes the buildup of the minerals in hard water, which leaves hair looking dull and makes it difficult for moisture to penetrate strands.Living Proof Perfect Hair Day High Shine Gloss, £30, livingproof.com An excellent new launch from one of the industry’s best haircare brands, High Shine Gloss does exactly what it says on the tin. Using a light-enhancing technology, it gives your hair the best shine ever. And unlike most hair glosses, it is lightweight and silicone free, so leaves no residue.‘Start with it on the long side’: Tom Smith on how to adapt to a new fringeFringe benefits: could you change things up with a new crop? Photograph: Jonathan Storey/Getty ImagesA great place to start is to gather up to three photos of fringe styles you like – ideally hair types and face shapes that resemble your own. Show these to your stylist and ask their advice on how to adapt the style to suit you best. Ask about what maintenance is required to have it looking like your photos and how often it will need to be trimmed (I have some clients who pop in for a fringe ‘dust’ every three weeks). Feel free to ask your stylist to cut your fringe on the longer side first, so you can assess and check how your hair naturally settles (this is something I’m in the habit of doing anyway) then, if required, slowly trim it shorter. Ask your stylist to show you an easy way to reset your fringe each morning. Something to note: fringes do typically require some form of tending to every day, so if your daily hair routine is currently minimal, having a fringe cut in may change that. Photograph: Pol Kurucz/B&A RepsDyson Supersonic Nural, £399, dyson.co.uk There has long been hype around Dyson. Hairstylists around the world swear by the brand. However, the smart gadgets do come at a price. So the question is: why? Perhaps we need to change our perspective on what Dyson creates. They consider everything from the way the product is shaped to fit your hand, to the weight and then, of course, how it works. The Supersonic Nural hairdryer – their smartest hairdryer yet, is launched this month. It is no ordinary dryer. It has a scalp protector-meets-hair-health sensor that is automatically reduced to 55C – the optimum temperature for scalp comfort and drying speed. It prioritises safety and has a motion sensor that automatically deactivates heat, while decreasing airflow and noise when you are in between styling. It considers everything: the ease and efficiency of the process; the finished results and the health of your hair. So is it worth it? Well, when you consider all the above, yes.GHD Chronos, £289, ghdhair.com Hair straightening is widely considered to be terrible for hair health – particularly if you fry your hair on a regular basis. But choosing the right flat iron limits the damage. The Chronos features cutting-edge ceramic heat technology that ensures the heat distribution across your hair is even. It does this by keeping the plates at a temperature that is high enough to give you a smooth, sleek finish, but not so high that you end up with crispy hair.BaByliss Air Power Pro, £150, boots.com A hairdryer that makes a lot of noise is pleasant to no one. Hence this excellent dryer by BaByliss is a godsend. Lightweight, powerful, performance driven… it has four temperature settings, three airflow settings, two styling concentrator nozzles and a wet-to-dry styling combination for all hair types and textures. It’s also one of the quietest.Hershesons The Wand, £120, hershesons.com Unless your hair is naturally poker straight, it should be able to hold a curl – with the right tools, expertise and styling products. Hershesons, the chic London hair salon headed up by A-list hairstylist Luke Hersheson, has channelled his years of experience into a product line, the most recent of which is the Wand. Super lightweight with a ceramic-coated barrel, which minimises heat damage, it has been created to work at just the right temperature to ensure your curls last and last and last, regardless of your hair type.Manta Detangling Brush, £30, mantahair.com A hairbrush is undoubtedly an anomaly in the world of tech-driven hair tools. And while the thought of a manual hair tool immediately reads like “a lot of work”, Manta makes the detangling process a breeze. Tim Mannington, a hairdresser with more than 25 years in the business, created Manta after his wife lost her hair through cancer. As she recovered and her hair began to grow back, she needed a brush that was effective yet gentle and minimised breakage. There are now numerous options for every hair type – even for babies.Shark SmoothStyle Hot Brush & Smoothing Comb, £79.99, sharkclean.co.uk This heated brush and comb gets the thumbs up for a few reasons. It is an all-in-one tool that works on both wet and dry hair. It styles, shapes and smooths with minimal heat damage. You can use it on any texture – straight, wavy or curly. In a time where high-priced hair tools have become the norm, having something that does all the above and is still under £100? That’s a win.Less can be more: how to cope with hair loss and what you can do to prevent thinningGood to go: hormone changes, poor diet, age and stress can all cause hair loss Photograph: Pol Kurucz/B&A RepsThe signs of hair loss are easy to spot: a thinner ponytail, more of your scalp showing when you part your hair, shorter hairs – particularly along your hairline – and, of course, increased shedding. Reasons include age, stress, change in hormones, deficiencies in diet, hairstyles that pull too tight (the latter is easy to treat – simply start wearing your hair in a different style). The others, however, are more complex and might need medical attention. That aside, there are things you can certainly do for starters: take regular high-quality hair supplements that incorporate hair- and scalp-strengthening vitamins. This will boost growth and minimise shedding. Use hair products that not only boost scalp health, target hair density and minimise hair loss. Living Proof’s Scalp Care Density Serum is a leave-in treatment infused with pea sprout and amaranth peptides to improve the appearance of thickness and density, but also reduces hair fallout rate. The Genesis haircare line by Kerastase is developed specifically to treat hair thinning (it also offers a hair-diagnostics service and in-salon treatments specifically to deal with this). Davines has a full range of products dedicated to treating hair loss. Typebea, a brand launched by beauty entrepreneur Anna Lahey and singer Rita Ora, has taken a different route from the usual celebrity brands to focus on products concerned with hair growth and hair thinning, while Nioxin offers shampoos and hair serums that will increase the appearance of thicker hair in eight weeks. Still, if you are really concerned about hair loss, it is worth seeing a trichologist. But do they work? Well, yes and no. The key to hair supplements, or any supplement, is to choose good quality(not ones that have numerous bulking agents) and to be consistent in taking them. That said, diet is key. The results of the trials are impressive – 34% reduction in hair loss in a month.The Nue Co Growth Phase, £65, uk.thenueco.com Balancing nutritional deficiencies, supporting hormonal health, calming stress and protecting against free radicals for longer, thicker, fuller hair is the mission of this supplement. The blend of vitamins, proteins and adaptogens will reduce hair loss and thinning in 90 days.Philip Kingsley Density Hair Complex, £33, philipkingsley.co.uk Philip Kingsley (the man was one of the world’s leading trichologists) knows a thing or two about hair. Its holistic approach to haircare means it understood the importance of hair and scalp health decades before it became trendy. Which is why all of its supplements include an essential blend of amino acids to ensure the maintenance of healthy hair.Ouai Thick and Full Supplements, £28, cultbeauty.co.uk One of the downsides with many supplements is the taste. Ouai – the brand founded by celebrity hair stylist Jen Atkin – has hair supplements that are formulated with a super-hydrating multivitamin complex to support hair strength – with no unpleasant aftertaste.‘A sharp bob suits anyone’: It’s chic and versatile, but needs maintenanceSnap to it: Anna Wintour. For the super-sharp bob, think fashion doyenne Anna Wintour, sans fringe, think Jessica Biel, more loose and liberated, think Ayo Edebiri. The undone, textured bob that made Alexa Chung the poster girl of the noughties is still going strong, too. There is the 50s Hollywood Baroque Bob, as seen on the likes of Zendaya. The versatility of the bob, explains Brixton Cowie, creative director at Neil Moodie Studio, is what makes it forever popular. ‘Its length can be adjusted to suit the wearer’s face and hair texture.’ But there is the issue of maintenance. According to Jay Birmingham, celebrity hairstylist and Tresemmé’s brand ambassador: ‘Most bobs require daily styling to stay looking chic.’ A textured bob can be more forgiving as it can be grown out into a ‘lob’ – a long bob. Your tool kit? Texturising spray, a diffuser for that ‘dried naturally’ style and, says Birmingham, a good hair oil, such as Lamellar Shine Oil from Tresemmé.Leave it to the experts: salon hair treatments that are both innovative and helpfulJo Hansford’s Metal Detox, johansford.com Chlorine in swimming pools, residue from the pipes of a soft water system, or hard water from your taps, can all leave traces of metal in your hair. Yes, you can now tackle it with an off-the-shelf product (see Colour Wow Dream Filter) but, for a professional approach, head to the Jo Hansford salon (below). Its Metal Detox treatment will neutralise and remove the metals and then protect the hair to prevent new particles from entering. (And you can keep up the good work at home with the Jo Hansford’s Metal Detox product line)Olaplex Bond Shaper Curl Rebuilding Treatment Pro Service, olaplex.com This curl-restoring salon service is a new treatment that restores coils to their never-before-seen glory. Using its now famous bond-building innovation, the professional treatment contains a blend of 23 amino acids and coconut-avocado milk to improve curl retention, control frizz, reduce breakage and increase overall strength. The results are outstanding.K18 Repair Service, K18hair.com For anyone that has experienced hair damage from heat styling, chemical processing or colour, this treatment from K18 is a must. It fortifies the hair leaving it smoother, bouncier and silkier. The results – which can be seen in less than 5 minutes – are accumulative – it will not disappear with your next shampoo.
